definitions.definition: measuring or covering a great length or distance, or a greater length or distance than usual

examples.text: She had long dark hair.
He walked down the long corridor.
It was the world's longest bridge.
a **long journey/walk/drive/flight**
We're **a long way** from anywhere here.
It's a **long way away**.
He had long, thin fingers.
a lush meadow of long grass
Economy class can be uncomfortable for those with long legs.
His drive to work is fairly long.
There was a long queue for tickets.
After the hurricane, many are forced to wait in very long lines to get food or gas.

definitions.definition: used for asking or talking about particular lengths or distances

examples.text: **How long** is the River Nile?
The table is six feet long.
The report is only three pages long.

definitions.definition: lasting or taking a great amount of time or more time than usual

examples.text: He’s been ill **(for) a long time**.
There was a long silence before she spoke.
I like it now the days are getting longer *(= it stays light for more time each day)*.
a **long book/film/list** *(= taking a lot of time to read/watch/deal with)*
Nurses have to work **long hours** *(= for more hours in the day than is usual)*.
He stared at them **for the longest time** *(= for a very long time)* before answering.
Chicago has **a long history of** country music.
to have a long life/career
an unusually long pause
He let out a long, slow breath.
It took me a long time to accept the situation.
Winters are long and severe in the far north.

definitions.definition: used for asking or talking about particular periods of time

examples.text: **How long** is the course?
I think it's only three weeks long.
How long a stay did you have in mind?

definitions.definition: seeming to last or take more time than it really does because, for example, you are very busy or not happy

examples.text: I'm tired. It's been a long day.
We were married for ten long years.

definitions.definition: covering all or most of your legs or arms

examples.text: She usually wears long skirts.
a long-sleeved shirt

definitions.definition: travelling a great distance

examples.text: The full-back intercepted an attempted long pass and ran through to score.
A hopeful long ball from out of defence led to a goal.
She's good with the driver and hits a long ball.

definitions.definition: travelling too far so that it goes out of play

examples.text: Her return of serve was long.

definitions.definition: having a lot of a particular quality

examples.text: The government is long on ideas but short on performance.

definitions.definition: a long vowel is pronounced for a longer time than other vowels

examples.text: Compare the long vowel in ‘beat’ and the short vowel in ‘bit’.

definitions.definition: very long

examples.text: There's a list of repairs as long as your arm.

definitions.definition: not longer than the particular time given

examples.text: It will take an hour at the longest.

definitions.definition: after a long time

examples.text: At long last his prayers had been answered.

definitions.definition: by a great amount

examples.text: He was the best by a long way.

definitions.definition: to have known each other for a long time

examples.text: We go back a long way, he and I.

definitions.definition: to last a long time

examples.text: She seems to make her money go a long way.
A small amount of this paint goes a long way *(= covers a large area)*.
I find that **a little of** Jerry's company can **go a long way** *(= I quickly get tired of being with him)*.

definitions.definition: to help very much/a little in achieving something

examples.text: The new law goes a long way towards solving the problem.

definitions.definition: to have made a lot of progress

examples.text: We've come a long way since the early days of the project.
The study of genes has come a long way in recent years.

definitions.definition: to need to make a lot of progress before you can achieve something

examples.text: She still has a long way to go before she's fully fit.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is no definite answer to a question

examples.text: ‘How long will it take?’ ‘How long's a piece of string?’

definitions.definition: relating to a longer period in the future

examples.text: This measure inevitably means higher taxes in the long run.

definitions.definition: used to describe what will happen a long, short, etc. time in the future

examples.text: Such a development seems unlikely, at least in the short term *(= it will not happen for quite a long time)*.
In the longer term, children of depressed mothers are more likely to suffer from childhood depression.
In the long term, our efforts will pay off.

definitions.definition: it makes no real difference which of two possible choices you make
used to say that the reasons for something are complicated and you would prefer not to give all the details
to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem

examples.text: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

definitions.definition: used when you are telling somebody the essential facts about something or what effect it will have, without explaining all the details
the power and/or authority of something

examples.text: There is no escape from the long arm of the law.

definitions.definition: (to have) an unhappy or disappointed expression

examples.text: He took one look at her long face and said ‘What’s wrong?’
The news for the company isn't good, to judge from the long faces in the boardroom.

definitions.definition: old or too old
an attempt or a guess that is not likely to be successful but is worth trying

examples.text: It's a long shot, but it just might work.

definitions.definition: used when you are saying that you will get to the point of what you are saying quickly, without including all the details

examples.text: To cut a long story short, we didn’t get home until 3 in the morning!
Anyway, long story short: we had this argument and I haven't seen him since.

definitions.definition: used to say hello to somebody you have not seen for a long time
not nearly; not at all

examples.text: It's not over yet—not by a long chalk.

definitions.definition: to consider a problem or possibility very carefully and without hurrying

examples.text: We need to take a long, hard look at all the options.

definitions.definition: to consider what is likely to happen or be important over a long period of time rather than only considering the present situation

examples.text: As pension funds are investing for members’ retirements, they can take the long view.

wordOrigin: adjective Old English lang, long (adjective), lange, longe (adverb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German lang.
